title: Residents say Ephrata Borough stinks: How the borough is working to fix the problem
text:
Ephrata residents complain about bad smell: How the borough is working to fix the problem
You may notice an unpleasant smell in a portion of Ephrata Borough.
People who live in the area say the foul odor has been around for a little over a year and continues to get worse.
One resident said the stench rotates between smelling like a dirty diaper pail and rotten eggs.
John Poucel, another borough resident, says, "It smells ungodly. I don't know, but sometimes it's okay. And then also you start getting a whiff, and you're like, 'Where is this coming from?'"
The borough says they are actively working to fix the stinky smell.
They say the wastewater plant located on the South Reading Road is to blame.
It's a plant that takes sewage and removes contaminants, making the waste safer for the environment.
But parts of the system were not functioning properly. The borough says they discovered this after an investigation last week, adding that is likely what's causing the rancid odor.
That system has been fixed, but it could take weeks for the smell to improve.
The facility was upgraded recently. And with the new technology, there can come some issues.
Ephrata Borough manager Nancy Harris says, "It's the second plant in the U.S. That's processing human waste that way. And the first one on the East Coast. So we have some growing pains. And unfortunately, it's impacting the residents in the area."
The borough says they are continuing to investigate what is happening at the treatment plant and want residents to know they are taking their concerns seriously.
